structured_info.title_cn: 驾驶员数字孪生及其在智能车辆中的使能技术综述与展望
structured_info.title_en: Review and Perspectives on Driver Digital Twin and Its Enabling Technologies for Intelligent Vehicles
structured_info.abstract: Digital Twin (DT) is introduced to digitize connected automated vehicles, but existing studies neglect driver digitization. This paper proposes Driver Digital Twin (DDT) to bridge automated systems and fully digitized driving human cyber-physical systems (H-CPS). DDT emphasizes multimodal state fusion, personalized modeling, and time variance for human-centric intelligent driving. Key enabling technologies are reviewed, applications discussed, and challenges outlined.
structured_info.methodology: Comprehensive literature review of driver modeling technologies (distraction detection, attention estimation, intention prediction, drowsiness detection, emotion monitoring, trust assessment, behavior recognition). Analysis of DDT architecture (real driver, digital driver, multimodal interface, applications) and implementation paradigms.
structured_info.conclusion: DDT provides a systematic framework for driver digitization, enabling harmonious human-centric driving systems. It enhances safety, personalization, and autonomous vehicle development but requires unified modeling, unsupervised data analysis, multimodal fusion, and regulatory solutions.

analysis.Overview: Proposes Driver Digital Twin (DDT) to digitize human drivers within intelligent vehicle ecosystems, addressing gaps in existing automated driving research by emphasizing personalized modeling and human-vehicle collaboration.
Background_and_Motivation: Research background: Existing Digital Twin (DT) focuses on vehicles/environments, neglecting driver digitization despite human centrality in driving systems.
Motivation: Lack of unified driver models limits full H-CPS development; DDT enables adaptive systems respecting human proactivity/sensitivity.
Necessity argument: Human drivers remain irreplaceable; personalized systems improve trust/acceptance of autonomous vehicles.
Broader significance: Completes intelligent driving H-CPS triad (human-vehicle-environment), enhancing system reliability/predictability.
Contributing disciplines: Transportation engineering, human-computer interaction, AI, cyber-physical systems, cognitive science.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: (1) DDT (virtual replica of driver capturing behavior/personality); (2) Multimodal fusion (integrating physiological/behavioral/vehicle data); (3) Human-CPS (integration of drivers into cyber-physical systems).
Concept relationships: DDT enables Human-CPS via multimodal fusion; personalized models feed into adaptive vehicle control.
Key assumptions: Drivers exhibit measurable patterns; sensor fusion can model driver states; personalization improves system acceptance.
Contribution type: Theoretical framework integrating disparate driver modeling research; novel emphasis on internal states (personality/capability) beyond physical tracking.
Methodology: Methods: Surveys vision-based (RGB/depth/IR), physiological (ECG/EEG/EMG), and vehicle-based (steering/pedal) sensors; reviews ML/DL models for state recognition.
Novelty/rationale: Proposes unified DDT framework beyond task-specific models; multimodal fusion improves robustness; lifelong learning enables adaptation.
Data: Public driving datasets (e.g., DR(eye)VE, DGW) and simulated data; preprocessing includes calibration/synchronization; representativeness limited by scenario/individual diversity.
Evaluation: Qualitative analysis of technology readiness; notes accuracy gaps between simulated (90%+) and real-world (70-90%) validation.
Theoretical paradigm: Aligns with cyber-physical-social systems (CPSS) and parallel intelligence; emphasizes human-in-the-loop design affecting human-vehicle collaboration focus.
Results: Key results: High accuracy (>90%) in controlled environments for distraction/drowsiness detection; lower real-world performance; DDT enables personalized ADAS/autonomous driving.
Significance/reliability: Demonstrates feasibility but highlights individual variability; sensor fusion improves reliability; time-variance modeling remains challenging.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structure: (1) Problem identification → (2) DDT concept proposal → (3) Architecture breakdown → (4) Technology review → (5) Application analysis → (6) Challenges/future work.
Key steps: Establishes driver modeling gap → argues DDT necessity → details implementation → validates via literature → identifies limitations.

Strengths: Comprehensive integration of multidisciplinary research; clear progression from theory to applications. Weaknesses: Limited empirical validation; handles rebuttals via challenge discussions (e.g., Section V).
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Holistic driver modeling framework; enables personalization in autonomous systems; bridges physical/digital driving domains.
Method limitations: Data scarcity for unified models; computational demands; real-time synchronization challenges.
Paradigm constraints: CPSS focus may underrepresent hardware/regulatory constraints; assumes sensor ubiquity in future vehicles.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Discourse role: Positions as foundational DDT framework; critiques vehicle-centric automation; advocates human-centered transition.
Terminology/rhetoric: Uses 'harmonious human-centric systems' as ideal; 'digitization urgency' as motivator; contrasts DDT with 'limited' prior work.
Authority building: Cites 299 references; uses IEEE Senior Member affiliations; motivations include unifying research and guiding industry adoption.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Conclusions: DDT completes driving H-CPS; requires multimodal fusion/personalization; benefits safety/acceptance; faces modeling/data challenges.
Future suggestions: Develop unified DDT frameworks; address data scarcity via unsupervised learning; establish regulations; explore skill-transfer applications.
